news_summary: Eight Central and Southern European countries, including Slovakia, are collaborating to connect their exchanges, enhancing regional cooperation and market integration.

news_summary_es: Ocho países de Europa Central y Meridional, entre ellos Eslovaquia, colaboran para conectar sus intercambios, reforzar la cooperación regional y la integración de los mercados.

articles.title: Kamenický welcomes that eight countries of Central and Southern Europe, including Slovakia, want to connect their exchanges
articles.summary: Slovak Finance Minister Ladislav Kamenický welcomes Croatia's initiative to connect exchanges between Central and Eastern European countries.
articles.content:
Bratislava/Zagreb – Eight countries of Central and Southern Europe, including Croatia, Bulgaria, Hungary, North Macedonia, Poland, Romania, and Slovenia, are joining a joint project to connect their capital markets, in addition to Slovakia. On behalf of the Slovak Republic, Finance Minister Ladislav Kamenický (Smer-SD) signed a memorandum of cooperation on Monday (August 25) in Zagreb, Croatia, mentioning the Union of Savings and Investments promoted by the European Commission, TASR reports.

Ladislav Kamenický informed on social media that discussions about the Union of Savings and Investments, formerly known as the Union of Capital Markets, have been ongoing at the European level for years, but negotiations at the level of EU finance ministers are still not concluded.

The Croatian initiative has managed to unite eight countries into a common regional solution

“I feel like some representatives are looking for more obstacles than real solutions. I am glad that the Croatian initiative has managed to unite eight countries into a common regional solution, which shows a real interest in implementation,” Kamenický assessed the situation.

According to him, the agreed cooperation creates stronger ties between the stock exchanges and financial institutions of the participating countries with the aim of connecting them. This is expected to allow investors from these countries to invest much more easily in Slovakia and vice versa.

“The project will not only bring more opportunities for investors, but the most important thing is that together we will start breaking down the imaginary barriers between our countries for the benefit of the economies and especially for the benefit of the citizens,” Kamenický added. (August 26)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a meaningful regional cooperation initiative connecting capital markets of eight Central and Southern European countries, which can enhance investment opportunities, economic integration, and benefit citizens broadly. It focuses on a single, significant development with clear positive economic and social implications beyond a small niche.
articles.personality_title: Eight European countries unite to connect their stock markets
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Eight countries in Central and Southern Europe have been discussing ways to join their stock markets to make investing easier across borders. This effort is part of a bigger plan called the Union of Savings and Investments, supported by the European Commission.

**What happened** – On August 25, Slovak Finance Minister Ladislav Kamenický signed an agreement in Zagreb, Croatia, along with representatives from Croatia, Bulgaria, Hungary, North Macedonia, Poland, Romania, and Slovenia. This agreement aims to connect their capital markets and stock exchanges to work together more closely.

**Impact** – This cooperation will make it simpler for people and businesses in these countries to invest in each other's markets. It will help break down barriers that usually make cross-border investing difficult. By joining forces, these countries hope to strengthen their economies and provide new chances for investors and citizens alike.

**What's next step** – The countries will work on implementing the agreement and connecting their financial systems. This project could lead to more regional partnerships and possibly encourage other European countries to join in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Eight Central and Southern European countries have agreed to link their stock markets, making investing easier and boosting regional economic ties.
articles.personality_title_fr: Huit pays européens unissent leurs marchés boursiers
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Huit pays d'Europe centrale et du sud discutent pour connecter leurs marchés boursiers afin de faciliter les investissements transfrontaliers. Ce projet fait partie de l'Union des Épargnes et des Investissements, soutenue par la Commission européenne.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 25 août, le ministre slovaque des Finances, Ladislav Kamenický, a signé un accord à Zagreb, en Croatie, avec des représentants de la Croatie, Bulgarie, Hongrie, Macédoine du Nord, Pologne, Roumanie et Slovénie. Cet accord vise à connecter leurs marchés financiers et bourses.

**Impact** – Cette coopération facilitera les investissements entre ces pays en supprimant les obstacles habituels. En unissant leurs forces, ils veulent renforcer leurs économies et offrir de nouvelles opportunités aux investisseurs et citoyens.

**Prochaine étape** – Les pays vont travailler à mettre en place cet accord et à connecter leurs systèmes financiers. Ce projet pourrait encourager d’autres pays européens à rejoindre cette initiative.

**Phrase résumé** – Huit pays d'Europe centrale et du sud ont décidé de relier leurs marchés boursiers pour faciliter les investissements et renforcer leurs liens économiques régionaux.
articles.personality_title_es: Ocho países europeos unen sus mercados bursátiles
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Ocho países de Europa Central y del Sur han estado hablando para conectar sus mercados bursátiles y así facilitar la inversión entre ellos. Este esfuerzo es parte de un plan mayor llamado Unión de Ahorros e Inversiones, respaldado por la Comisión Europea.

**Qué pasó** – El 25 de agosto, el ministro de Finanzas de Eslovaquia, Ladislav Kamenický, firmó un acuerdo en Zagreb, Croacia, junto con representantes de Croacia, Bulgaria, Hungría, Macedonia del Norte, Polonia, Rumania y Eslovenia. El acuerdo busca conectar sus mercados de capital y bolsas.

**Impacto** – Esta cooperación hará más fácil que personas y empresas inviertan en los mercados de estos países. Ayudará a eliminar barreras que dificultan la inversión entre fronteras y fortalecerá las economías regionales.

**Próximo paso** – Los países trabajarán para implementar el acuerdo y conectar sus sistemas financieros. Este proyecto podría motivar a otros países europeos a unirse en el futuro.

**Frase para llevar** – Ocho países de Europa Central y del Sur acordaron conectar sus mercados bursátiles para facilitar la inversión y fortalecer lazos económicos regionales.
